There is no perfect model to caring for children in poverty. We always should be striving to get better at it, and so far the model I like is enabling the locals who wish they could do more for their community, learning from past models, seeking ensure the family can stay intact, etc. I heard from some Indian family members that in India some organizations' models enabled abuse in the form of a sort of pressured conversion to Christianity. Like "if you convert we will make sure you get the help you need" in order to fulfill some sort of expectation from the western world for Christian converts due to the work being done. That was very concerning to hear - that so many organisations were apparently party to this abuse in India. Our expectations for what outcome we (the sponsors) want might look different in practice.
So, to respond to the model of this charity, Not Forgotten, if possible I'd prefer the families stay together. This is complex, of course, but if say the mum (I'm Aussie) is willing to have her son back home if she gets the help needed to raise him, I prefer that much more than this model. Now Not Forgotten model seems far better for the children than a standard "throw the kids into a house and the staff will sort them out" sort of idea. When there's abuse and abandonment things get really really tough when seeking to reunite families. There is no simple, easy solution to poverty, and so it's good to approach the issue in multifaceted ways. I appreciate the efforts of Destin and the team who are invested in this project. We just don't want disillusioned kids stepping out of this program with no connection to their biological family or community.

While I totally support your cause I want to point out that this (providing orphans a family) is not unique. SOS children's village is doing exactly this for over 70 years now, providing for more than 50,000 children in over 130 countries.

The Milton Hershey school is modeled the same way as this only it is also available to children from financially challenged homes as well. The school is funded by Hershey E&T (Hershey Park, the Hotel Hershey, the Hershey Lodge, the Hershey Country Club, Houlihan's bar and grill, Devon Seafood and grill, the Giant Center, the Hershey Campgrounds, the Hershey Gardens, the Hershey Nursery, Hershey Bears Hockey and all of the Cocoa Beanery Cafes and Cafe Zooka).

This is awesome. I myself work for a company dedicates to ending child poverty and homelessness. My region depot sends to Zambia in Africa.

I am being 100% honest to people when I say this type of work will change your whole mindset.

I was drinking and drowning in my own iniquity..... Gambling, Alcohol, etc. But once I realize now there are kids starving with swollen stomachs not even 1 grain of rice to eat and I was (at my very worst) won and lost again 7k euro in less than 7 hours, I changed my whole life.

And through the job I have met some of the truly beautiful people of the world. People who understand love is the greatest currency of all. There's maybe 300+ people in our building all constantly smiling and very rarely stressed. We all have fun and laughs everyday.

I would advise anyone out there who like giving to try find a job in this line of work. It can really make your whole life positive.

To those who are complaining that this project ignores girls:
The fact that a child has a Y chromosome doesn't prohibit compassion. Your comments are complaints that money is being spent on heart disease instead of cancer. https://youtu.be/Wp9NUrNssv8?t=28s At no point do they say that they're happy about girls being pushed into prostitution. Instead you have a situation where both boys and girls need help and nobody was helping any of them.

To help the girls, they'd have had to come up with a plan by which a few people could effectively take children from their mothers. It's a horrible situation for the girls and they should be helped, but still, how do you do that in a society that permits it, especially from the other side of the world? As some have pointed out in the comments, creating good men who have experienced this situation is one possible way to affect change in the culture overall. It's not fast, but it could be effective.

Finally, they're doing what they could. They clearly have devoted a large amount of their own time and money to do good. Heck, if they had set up a shelter to help the stray dogs in that town, that's more than I am doing, and I'd be willing to bet it's more than 99% of the viewers of this video are doing. They're alleviating suffering to the best of their abilities, why complain?
Werid question but, why is that there's only boys, and not girls? Are boys more likely to be orphans?

To the people arguing religion in the comments: I just wanted to point out that Destin has done videos at Skepticon about people who love his channel but hate that he's a Christian. He's also mentioned that he wants everyone (religious or not) watching his videos so they can learn. I'm pretty sure he doesn't need you to white knight for him, especially not when you do a very poor job of it. People are allowed to be made uncomfortable by things and telling people to 'leave' or calling them 'stupid' for it isn't any way for a Christian to be behaving. Be an example, don't get mad because to non-believers your point of view is like riding a backward bike. Falling to name calling, aggression, and cruelty only convinces non-believers that they're right about you and that they're right about Christianity.

Those of you upset that religion is a part of this system: I understand, but keep in mind that Peru is already highly converted. Most of these children have already been raised with Catholicism as 81.3% of the country follows that particular brand of Christianity. I'm not saying you should be comfortable with it, one would hope that since Destin is involved that the brand of Christianity being taught here is a good one, but I am saying that likely these kids already believe and already believe the bad things. I trust that Destin would support a system that teaches the true lessons of Jesus, and one that can help these kids unlearn bad prejudices. We know for a fact Destin is making sure these kids get a good science education, so how about we trust that he's keeping an eye out for their religious one? I wish / hope that it involves learning about other religious options, including other forms of Christianity and things like Buddhism and non-religion, mostly because when Catholicism was spread to Peru it nearly wiped out their native religion entirely. I wish / hope that these kids will be supported if they decide that religion isn't for them, because it's their choice and forcing any type of religious belief (or lack of belief) onto anyone has not historically gone well.

This is a beautiful charity, I will admit that my money is going to remain a bit more local for donations this year. No child is more important than another, but at least with more local charities I can actually physically go help them. Flying to Peru is kind of outside of my wheelhouse.
